reviewText: Christmas in Canaan is an amazing story of how all people, regardless of race, religion, or color, should love one another. My favorite part was when there was no money at Christmas and dad (Billy Ray) had the great idea of cutting out "wishes" from the catalog and gaily wrapping them in boxes with bows. The children accepted his gifts, knowing there was no money for the real thing. The black young man in the movie ran with the idea and when he became a famous author came back to have Christmas with this family, who had taken him in when his grandmother died and left him an orphan. His surprise was that he fullfilled the catalog wishes with the real thing!  This was a movie that brings tears to the eyes and urges you to do better in relationships. This is a great movie to watch with your kids and talk about the issue of racism.  It certainly is a step toward eradicating it.  I told a white friend of mine who has two black children she has adopted - "I don't see them as black children.  They are just your children!"  I really do see it that way. Enjoy!

reviewText: This is one of the most unique Christmas movies I have ever seen. It is heart warming and flows smoothly. The real meaning of Christmas is lived out in a small Texas town in the lives of a family. This movie is reverent, exciting, and entertaining covering the lives of a poor small farming family and how the father (wife deceased) deals not only with Christmas on a low budget but problems that arise from life in the south. A good solid Christian film for all ages.

reviewText: Definitely a different Christmas movie. Billy Ray Cyrus can act and sing well. He performs and wrote "We'll Get By Somehow" the theme song for "Christmas in Canaan" in which he plays the widower dad, Daniel Burton. His oldest, DJ (young: Zak Ludwig; teen: Jacob Blair) is played well by both actors. DJ makes friends with a black boy Rodney (youth: Jaishon Fisher; older: Matt Ward) after saving a pup shot with a gun. At that point the story jumps ahead 7 years. Both the Burton family and the black, Freeman family are poor, living in Canaan, TX, in the 1960, complete with Afro-hair, and bell bottoms.There is a combined plot/theme of racism and overcoming bigotry, the black vote, and family in this Texas Western which includes beater pick-ups, not horses. Only one gun shot but several heart-touching scenes. A Black Vote meeting ends in tragedy. The children lead the way to promise and HOPE in Canaan, TX. One line says; "Once your family, you always got a place", and this DVD's always got a place in our Christmas DVD collection. Five stars from me and also from my wife. We're thinking of ordering more for Christmas gifts.Story is based on a book written by Kenny Rogers and Donald Davenport. Davenport also wrote the teleplay. There are no bonus materials, but it did have Closed Caption. 90 minutes of good FAMILY ENTERTAINMENT, with a message. The message: HOPE. PEACE, GOODWILL TO ALL COLORS.
summary: COMBINES CHRISTMAS, TEXAS, FAMILY, AND HOPE

reviewText: What I Can Tell You: Christmas in Canaan is a beautiful story of acceptance, bravery and friendship. I loved it!  I must have cried three times which is to be expected because I am a great big sap. Billy Ray is perfect in the role of Daniel, "the dad".  I was truly touched with his attempts to give his family gifts from the heart for the holidays. While the movie covers a difficult subject, the beginning of the civil rights movement and prejudice, you will walk away seeing the subtle ways the film establishes that we are all the same underneath the color of our skin.The friendship of the boys is my favorite part of the movie although I feel some of the lesson will be lost on younger children. My children have no idea that there is a difference or that at a time, people were treated differently. They were confused as to why people would try to burn down a building, or dislike people. They have no idea what bigotry is and some of words used by the two boys on the school bus I talked over so they wouldn't learn them. Not bad words just needless words.This is a great movie for 13+ and anyone who loves a good Christmas feel good movie
